title: Changing Victim's JIRA Integration Settings Through Multiple Bugs

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**

Changing victim's JIRA integration settings through multiple bugs.

**Description:**

Using multiple HackerOne bugs, an attacker can change the victim's JIRA integration settings.

### Bugs:

###1) The Jira integration consent screen lacks information about the Jira project that will be connected to HackerOne

{F181926}
***Malicious or good Jira trying to connect above?***
Impossible to know without clicking on `Link JIRA Instance to program`, this is bad.

###2) JIRA project automatic selection

When a user already have a JIRA connected to his HackerOne program, if an attacker sends 
a malicious link to him (with a malicious JIRA JWT token in it), clicking on `Link JIRA Instance to program` will change the JIRA account connected to the program and worst, it will automatically select the attacker's JIRA project without user interaction. Any new HackerOne report will be cloned to the attacker's JIRA project.

###3) Bypassing HackerOne link protection

[Link protection bypass](https://hackerone.com/users/%2E/saml/sign_in?email=teste@hackerone.com)

###4) HackerOne SAML Open Redirector ( #171398 )

###5) Jira OAuth CSRF

{F181925}

{F181924}

### Conclusion:

An attacker can use all bugs above in many ways to try to link his own JIRA project to the victim's HackerOne program.

### Optional: Supporting Material/References (Screenshots)

 * Video #1 (bugs #1 and #2 demonstration): https://youtu.be/Tx1EalW554M
 * Video #2 (bug #5 demonstration): https://youtu.be/OBZkiyI-9zI
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

Changing victim's JIRA integration settings through multiple bugs.

Description:

Using multiple HackerOne bugs, an attacker can change the victim's JIRA integration settings.

Bugs:

1) The Jira integration consent screen lacks information about the Jira project that will be connected to HackerOne


Malicious or good Jira trying to connect above?
Impossible to know without clicking on Link JIRA Instance to program, this is bad.

2) JIRA project automatic selection

When a user already have a JIRA connected to his HackerOne program, if an attacker sends
a malicious link to him (with a malicious JIRA JWT token in it), clicking on Link JIRA Instance to program will change the JIRA account connected to the program and worst, it will automatically select the attacker's JIRA project without user interaction. Any new HackerOne report will be cloned to the attacker's JIRA project.

3) Bypassing HackerOne link protection

Link protection bypass

4) HackerOne SAML Open Redirector ( #171398 )

5) Jira OAuth CSRF

Conclusion:

An attacker can use all bugs above in many ways to try to link his own JIRA project to the victim's HackerOne program.

Optional: Supporting Material/References (Screenshots)

  • Video #1 (bugs #1 and #2 demonstration): https://youtu.be/Tx1EalW554M
  • Video #2 (bug #5 demonstration): https://youtu.be/OBZkiyI-9zI

activities.message: In a few hours, I will provide a PoC using bugs #1, #2, #3 and #4 together.
activities.markdown_message: In a few hours, I will provide a PoC using bugs #1, #2, #3 and #4 together.

I will send a video PoC in a few hours.

Thanks.

activities.message:
PoC (using #1, #2, #3 and #4 as a bug chain):

https://youtu.be/fFiAspJAFio
https://youtu.be/y2BZYoqSfvQ

"Evil.com" source-code:

```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
	<body>
	<script>
		window.open('https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=3b38f53d6b06dde2ebc1cb0e88339599dfcceea2&url=https%3A%2F%2Fpastebin.com%2FUHqzVwMx', '_blank');
		top.document.location.href = 'https://hackerone.com/apps/atlassian/claim-app?jwt=teste';
	</script>
	</body>
</html>
```

[Comment 1655437](https://hackerone.com/bugs?report_id=226199#activity-1655437) will make more sense now.

<!DOCTYPE html>

        window.open('https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=3b38f53d6b06dde2ebc1cb0e88339599dfcceea2&url=https%3A%2F%2Fpastebin.com%2FUHqzVwMx', '_blank');
        top.document.location.href = 'https://hackerone.com/apps/atlassian/claim-app?jwt=teste';

</html>

Comment 1655437 will make more sense now.

activities.message: Thanks for looking into our JIRA integration! Our team is investigating your report.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for looking into our JIRA integration! Our team is investigating your report.

activities.message:
Hello @whhackersbr, 

Thanks for looking into our JIRA Marketplace integration! It's pretty new, and we're excited to see reports like yours that will make HackerOne safer!

To understand what's going on, I'll give you an insight on how installing the HackerOne Atlassian Marketplace installation works. 

After installing our plugin on your JIRA instance, we've to link it with on of your HackerOne programs. Atlassian calls this tenant linking. We've to do is this:

{F182091}

When you're installing the app, the JIRA instance fires a call to our application; this contains the JIRA id and the shared secret (API key).  At this point we don't know whose installation send this information to us, we'll store it and wait for a claim.

After installation, the JIRA plugin offers a "Get Started" flow. In this flow, we'll link the JIRA instance to the unclaimed installation. To do this safely, we've to do these steps:

- (1) The user gets redirected from JIRA to our site. To authorize the user, JIRA sends a signed JWT along. Using a secret (yup, the one we currently don't know), you can validate if the request comes from JIRA and who's logged in.

- (2) We can't validate, so we'll unpack the JWT token to figure out what the JIRA id is.

- (3) Using this JIRA id, we can look for an unclaimed installation and figure out what the secret key is.

- (4) We'll unpack the original JWT key again, but this time using the shared secret and JIRA id. If validation fails, we know it's not the original request. If it passes, we know it's the real deal.

- (5) Since we now know the current_user and the unclaimed installation, we'll store the owner to the unclaimed installation

- (6) Now we give you the dropdown with all the teams you have access to modify the integrations. After linking, we'll delete the unclaimed installation since it's not unclaimed anymore.

Note that we've to complete 1->5 within the expiration time of the JWT token. Replay attacks must be completed within the expiration time of the JWT token. But it's not that complicated to get a new JWT token.

In this report, the attacker captures the redirect from JIRA to HackerOne. He now tricks the program to go to that link and connect the malicious instance to the victim's program. Note that the victim must be a manager of the team and has to claim the install. 

I've just pushed a change that makes social engineering of this feature harder. We're warning the user to be sure the instance they are connecting to is theirs. The claim page is now showing the user what JIRA instance URL they are about to connect. 

{F182088}
*^ the new and improved claim page*

Do you have suggestions on how we can make social engineering of this endpoint even harder? I'm curious to know.

Thanks,

Willian
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @whhackersbr,

Thanks for looking into our JIRA Marketplace integration! It's pretty new, and we're excited to see reports like yours that will make HackerOne safer!

To understand what's going on, I'll give you an insight on how installing the HackerOne Atlassian Marketplace installation works.

After installing our plugin on your JIRA instance, we've to link it with on of your HackerOne programs. Atlassian calls this tenant linking. We've to do is this:

When you're installing the app, the JIRA instance fires a call to our application; this contains the JIRA id and the shared secret (API key). At this point we don't know whose installation send this information to us, we'll store it and wait for a claim.

After installation, the JIRA plugin offers a "Get Started" flow. In this flow, we'll link the JIRA instance to the unclaimed installation. To do this safely, we've to do these steps:

  • (1) The user gets redirected from JIRA to our site. To authorize the user, JIRA sends a signed JWT along. Using a secret (yup, the one we currently don't know), you can validate if the request comes from JIRA and who's logged in.

  • (2) We can't validate, so we'll unpack the JWT token to figure out what the JIRA id is.

  • (3) Using this JIRA id, we can look for an unclaimed installation and figure out what the secret key is.

  • (4) We'll unpack the original JWT key again, but this time using the shared secret and JIRA id. If validation fails, we know it's not the original request. If it passes, we know it's the real deal.

  • (5) Since we now know the current_user and the unclaimed installation, we'll store the owner to the unclaimed installation

  • (6) Now we give you the dropdown with all the teams you have access to modify the integrations. After linking, we'll delete the unclaimed installation since it's not unclaimed anymore.

Note that we've to complete 1->5 within the expiration time of the JWT token. Replay attacks must be completed within the expiration time of the JWT token. But it's not that complicated to get a new JWT token.

In this report, the attacker captures the redirect from JIRA to HackerOne. He now tricks the program to go to that link and connect the malicious instance to the victim's program. Note that the victim must be a manager of the team and has to claim the install.

I've just pushed a change that makes social engineering of this feature harder. We're warning the user to be sure the instance they are connecting to is theirs. The claim page is now showing the user what JIRA instance URL they are about to connect.


^ the new and improved claim page

Do you have suggestions on how we can make social engineering of this endpoint even harder? I'm curious to know.

Thanks,

Willian

activities.message:
Hey @wvdv,

First of all, thanks for the awesome answer, I know that you have hundreds of reports to read and answer every day, so receiving such a detailed explanation is an honor to me (because of your explanation, I made a few other tests and found another unrelated bug, a CSRF, I will report it soon).

The new claim page is perfect, totally fixes bug #1.

You can make social engineering harder, fixing bugs #2 and #3.

Bug #2:

When a user configures JIRA integration for the first time, he needs to select a project in the configuration settings page:

{F182234}
{F182235}

But if the user already configured JIRA in the past and claims another install (because of a social engineering attack or another bug), the project will be auto-selected (a project with the same ID of the old installation):

{F182236}
***(Attacker's project auto-selected)***

You could ask the user to select the project again since it is a new install.
If it is a malicious install, the user will see project names that he never saw before (the attacker would need to know the JIRA project names of the victim, very unlikely) and he will not select any.

Bug #3 is easy to fix:

[Link Protection Working](https://hackerone.com/users/saml/sign_in?email=teste@snapchat.com)
[Link Protection Not Working](https://hackerone.com/users/%2E/saml/sign_in?email=teste@snapchat.com)
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @wvdv,

First of all, thanks for the awesome answer, I know that you have hundreds of reports to read and answer every day, so receiving such a detailed explanation is an honor to me (because of your explanation, I made a few other tests and found another unrelated bug, a CSRF, I will report it soon).

The new claim page is perfect, totally fixes bug #1.

You can make social engineering harder, fixing bugs #2 and #3.

Bug #2:

When a user configures JIRA integration for the first time, he needs to select a project in the configuration settings page:


But if the user already configured JIRA in the past and claims another install (because of a social engineering attack or another bug), the project will be auto-selected (a project with the same ID of the old installation):


(Attacker's project auto-selected)

You could ask the user to select the project again since it is a new install.
If it is a malicious install, the user will see project names that he never saw before (the attacker would need to know the JIRA project names of the victim, very unlikely) and he will not select any.

Bug #3 is easy to fix:

Link Protection Working
Link Protection Not Working

activities.message: P.S.: Did you push the new claim page to prod?

activities.message: Hey @whhackersbr, just want to let you know we're looking into your suggestions.
activities.markdown_message: Hey @whhackersbr, just want to let you know we're looking into your suggestions.

activities.message:
Hey @whhackersbr, 

We've discussed with the team on how to handle the other bugs you've reported. Although we agree the UX is a bit confusing (read: broken), and we should fix it, it's not imposing a security thread. Therefore we'll not prioritise changing the current behaviour. However, in our next integration, we'll fix these UX issues and hopefully backport it to the current JIRA setup flow.

Thanks for making HackerOne safe!

Willian
activities.markdown_message:

Thanks for making HackerOne safe!

Willian

activities.message:
Hi @whhackersbr,

Yes, you can test again.

Thanks, @whhackersbr, for the great report and for helping us test new functionality to ensure it's secure.

We're also including a bonus bounty for the extra collaboration you offered in reproducing and fixing this issue.

As always, we look forward to your future reports. Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks, @whhackersbr, for the great report and for helping us test new functionality to ensure it's secure.

We're also including a bonus bounty for the extra collaboration you offered in reproducing and fixing this issue.

As always, we look forward to your future reports. Happy hacking!
